case_vignette: A 5-year-old male with a past medical history of well-controlled eczema presents with light colored patches on the face and forearms noticed by the patient's parents a few days ago! Parents deny any trauma to the sites or any new topical products! Patient denies any pruritus or pain at the affected areas! Examination of the face reveals poorly demarcated ovoid hypopigmented patches on the cheeks and forearms!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have light colored patches on my face and forearms.
How long have you noticed these patches?
I noticed the patches a few days ago.
Have the patches changed in size or appearance since you first noticed them?
No, the patches have not changed in size or appearance since I first noticed them.
Do the patches itch or cause any discomfort?
No, the patches do not itch or cause any discomfort.
Do you have any previous history of skin conditions, or does anyone in your family have similar skin issues?
I have a history of well-controlled eczema.
Are the patches completely lacking color, or are they just lighter than your normal skin tone?
The patches are just lighter than my normal skin tone.
Have you started using any new skincare products, medications, or been exposed to new materials recently?
No, I haven't used any new skincare products, medications, or been exposed to new materials recently.
**Final Diagnosis:** Tinea versicolor.
